content: I love this game, from the way that the numbers are built up, to the way that kids have to purchase (with pretend coins) access to a new level. The puzzles are such a fun way to play with the numbers, developing creative, individualized use of addition and subtraction. The tallest ladders do get a little unwieldy, but it's not a huge problem. I like the bombs in the ladders. It encourages precision, but doesn't give any sort of a FAIL response, just a OOPS, TRY AGAIN. I even recommend this app to my college students who express a phobia with basic calculations. It's a great way to build fluency with smaller numbers, and also reinforce the flexible nature of math.
replyContent: Hi Kendra, Thank you so much for your review and feedback. We are happy to hear about your experiences and thoughts behind the educational aspect of the game. Great to hear that it served as a helpful tool for your kids and college students. Good luck with the practice! Regards, DragonBox Support

content: This is the best math game i have seen to develop number sense. I'm excited to introduce it to my students, and I love that it does not seem baby-ish. It makes it more accessible to older students who need support with addition/subtraction.

content: Can you please add halfs like all the odd numbers can split in half. Not like three makes 1 and 2 I mean like 1 1/2 and 1 1/2.
replyContent:
It would feel very natural to split the Nooms into decimals! For pedagogical reasons, we have decided not to do it in Numbers. We focus here on Number Sense, and we find it best to introduce this concept with solely whole numbers. 
But we are always working on the many possibilities offered by our digital rods, so yes, decimals are on our minds!

As parents, we have to take more responsibility in being personally involved in our children's education. Please don't expect our educational system to do everything. Try these products and you will not be sorry! My only comment is that when you get to Algebra, START OUT, on the 12 and up instead of the 5 and up. To me, they begin almost identically anyway and I think if you had going from one to the next that they may become discouraged because they have to essentially start over on the 12 and up version.

content: My kids love this and really get a tangible understanding of the abstract concept of numbers and manipulating them with addition and subtraction...all while playing a game!

I am changing stars from 3 to 5!! It's great... I bought it as a teacher and the kids (4 years old) think that it is fantastic. It has become the most requested activity in the class. I would like to make a suggestion though since I bought it as an educator and NOT a parent (I saw the review on the IB Magazine)... Only 4 users?? That is great for parents but not for teachers. It is so demotivating for the kids to have to start again. Any chance of a way to solve this? Thanks Nick
replyContent:
Hello Nick, adding languages is a costly work (because of the voices!), so we're going slowly with them. Does the lack of Italian really take us 2 stars ? :) I've seen kids learn to count in foreign language, like English thanks to this app!

As for teachers, we are looking into how to best fit this into our offer.

content: My daughter loves it. Worth the money. No annoying ads, just painless fun with a side effect of learning to add and subtract.

I have tried a huge number of maths games for my 5 year old. Most are rubbish, some are good, a few are great and an occasional one is fantastic. But this game blows all others out of the water, for the fact that it's as fun as some of the best non-educational games, yet amidst all the fun it's teaching arithmatic so well that it soon becomes intuitive. Learning just happens without the child even realising they're being taught. A game this good deserves an award! Just get it!
replyContent: Thank you Jthan ! We're working on awards :)

Brilliant!

Dragon box has become my favourite app producing company for pre-schoolers. The original dragonbox program was my favourite. It was quite amazing to see my four year old work through the different levels. He and I were compelled. However in some ways it was not obvious that this really had great educational benefit for such a small child. Who knows what he would remember in the future?  This one is just fantastic. Even after a couple of days play it was clear my son was gaining much greater facility with numbers and more than that was completely charmed by the program. I think this beats my previous favourite maths apps made by montesouri and really I think most four to six year olds could benefit from it as they start to discover the properties of numbers.  Only complaint. The app seemed to ask for a lot of privileges when I installed it. I denied most of these, especially about giving access to my phones call facility(?). It seems to work fine but I wonder if this means I will now not get emailed about my son¬¥s progress? Some info clarifying all of this would be helpful DragonBox.
My 4.5 year old now routinely asks math questions at dinner. And exclaims 'I'm doing math!' A+ on this "game."
Another great game from the makers of Dragonbox.  Unlike most math games that just add sounds and graphics to quizzes, this is a game made from the rules of math.  Buy this for your kid right now.
You are a genius. You got into the kids mind. Awsome all three games! We need more people like you in Education.
